sec.title: Jeremy Schipper, Disability and Isaiah’s Suffering Servant, Biblical Refigurations, Oxford University Press: Oxford, 2011; 208 pp.: 9780199594856, £45.00 (£22.50)/$65.00 (hbk); 9780199594863, £14.99/$27.95 (pbk)
sec.p: In his book, Disability and Isaiah’s Suffering Servant, Jeremy Schipper raises an important question that scholarship has tended to ignore regarding the subject of disability, when interpreting the Scriptures. He claims that, although disability imagery is ubiquitous in the Hebrew Bible, characters with disabilities are not much in evidence, and tries to establish the Suffering Servant in Isaiah 53 as a biblical character with disabilities, aiming to show that disability language is lost in translation. He claims there are physical and social implications from an injured, killed, recovered and prisoner Servant. Arguing that disability language is lost in typology, Schipper makes no distinction between typology and metaphor within the ‘literal sense’ of Scripture. Reference to blind and deaf imagery may not speak of disability, since Isaiah 6 uses this metaphor to describe Judah’s unwillingness to hear the prophetic word, and blindness and deafness in Isaiah 40—55 refer to Isaiah 6 and not ‘literal’ reference to disabilities. Whether or not such an argument is correct, Schipper shows how narrow traditional interpretations are when considering the Servant or other biblical characters.

Admirable as his project is, Schipper overlooks the extensive nature of twentieth-century scholarship, not to mention work on the formation of Isaiah, medieval rabbinic exegesis and recent works about the role of the Servant. While his Targumic treatment underscores that early Judaism did not foresee a suffering messiah, more extensive research is needed before addressing this commendable topic. Overlooking how Isaiah 40—66 was trisected into three equal parts, developing the Servant from collective (40—48) to individual (49—57) and ‘servants’ (58—66), Schipper imposes a ‘collective reference’ on Isaiah 52.13—53.12 while ignoring scholarship that demonstrates how the first three Servant Songs have a different meaning from the fourth song. He also overlooks the ‘functional ambiguity’ of the fourth song, which allows for a variety of interpretations. His section on messianism is quite weak and shows little awareness of this subject, including my Messianism within the Scriptural Scroll of Isaiah (2007). Schipper needs to move beyond pre-biblical levels of Deutero-Isaiah to the later scriptural form of the book when later editors reshaped Deutero-Isaiah into a greater corpus.

Inviting biblical readers into new hermeneutical horizons, Schiffer’s work will cause scholars to step back and re-examine disabilities but it requires more advanced research. This thoughtful, compassionate and imaginative work warns biblical scholars against closing their hearts to other interpretive options. It is accessible to both scholars and general readers but betrays how topical study or themes cannot be imposed on biblical literature.
